intro: Chaptalia paramensis, commonly known as the Paramense chaptalia, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in high-altitude grasslands and is known for its small, clustered flowers that bloom in the summer. Its leaves are often used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species.
